value.0: An embodiment of hellfire, this powerful magical blade is designed to vanquish the forces of good.
A cloak which completely hides the body of the wearer, making their hands and actions below the neck harder to see.

Using me will set your PC Key. Please read my conversation carefully, especially if you're new to Amia.

Click me again to enter the Travel Agency. From there, you can go to any of the locations you wish by clicking one of the location banners. You can also read the tomes regarding the two sections of Amia that we house: the main isle of Amia and the various surrounding regions.

If you are new to Amia, we recommend you choose the Wave & Serpent Adventuring Guild statue, rather than one of the flags. This will take you to the primary start location for our server.

Have fun and thank you for joining us on Amia!
Click me to Enter the Game

Use this console to convert your kobold, goblin, or orc to the Dynamic models, which allows a greater range of customization.

You will be booted for the changes to take affect after confirming the change.

Note: This only works for kobolds and goblins if your PC is male. If you have made a female goblin or kobold, flag down a DM to either change you to male (kobold or goblin) or to get female head and skin tone options (goblin).

Amia supports the following Races openly, selectable at character creation:

DWARF : Shield Dwarf (default), Gold Dwarf

ELF : Moon Elf (default), Drow, Sun Elf, Wild Elf, Wood Elf

GNOME : Rock Gnome (default), Svirfneblin

HALF-ELF : Half-Elf (default), Half-Drow, Elfling

HALFLING : Lightfoot Halfling (default), Ghostwise Halfling, Strongheart Halfling

HALF-ORC : Half-Orc (default)

HUMAN : Non-regional (default), Calishite, Chultan, Damaran, Durpari, Ffolk, Halruaan, Mulan, Tuigan

MONSTERS : Duergar, Bugbear, Goblin, Hobgoblin, Kobold, Orc, Ogrillon, Orog (These races can only be of non-good alignment, unless you submit a request on the forums asking otherwise.)

-------------------------------

The following races can be chosen only with SHIELD DWARF, MOON ELF, ROCK GNOME, HALF-ELF (default), LIGHTFOOT HALFLING, HALF-ORC (default), HUMAN (default):

     Aasimar
     Air Genasi
     Earth Genasi
     Fire Genasi
     Water Genasi
     Tiefling

-------------------------------

The following functional races are also available with a DM approved request:

     ELF ONLY: Aquatic Elf, Avariel, Fey'ri
     HUMAN ONLY: Kenku, Lizardfolk, Shadovar
     UNIVERSAL: Half-Dragon

For information on these races which require DM permission, visit www.amiaworld.com and check the Special Character Requests subforum in the Requests section of the forum.

IMPORTANT: CLICK THE STATUE TO ACTIVATE YOUR SUBRACE IF YOU ARE ONE OF THE FOLLOWING:
     Aasimar
     Tiefling
     Feytouched
     Air, Earth, Fire, or Water Genasi
     Request Only: Aquatic Elf
     Request Only: Fey'ri
     Request Only: Elfling
     Request Only: Shadovar


Most races on Amia are available at character creation. The few which require a bit more than simply clicking the right option are: Aasimar, Tiefling, Feytouched, Fire/Earth/Air/Water Genasi, Aquatic Elf, Fey'ri, Elfling, and Shadovar.


Generally speaking, these indicated subraces require little more than choosing the appropriate "base" race (which is one of the default Neverwinter Nights races, like Moon Elf or Shield Dwarf) and typing the appropriate keyword into the Subrace field in the race selection screen. The keyword is not case-sensitive, but make sure you spell it right or you'll have to redo the character!

***After you have done this, your subrace will automatically activate when you click the statue to enter the server.***


The stats presented in the tables on the website override the racial modifiers for the "base" race you choose for those indicated above (for example, you will not receive both Moon Elf and Fire Genasi ability adjustments). This can be a little confusing, since the abilities you put into the Ability screen at character creation won't reflect accurately on one of these other subraces. Just try to keep in mind that moon elves will receive +2 CON and -2 DEX before applying Fire Genasi +2 INT and -2 CHA. You can see a clearer example of this on the Amia Races page on the forums.


NOTE: Some races require a request before they can be played on Amia. These races are marked with "Requires DM Permission" in their listing on the forum (Aquatic Elf, Fey'ri, Elfling, and Shadovar). Starting a character with non-standard skin tones, body types, skin changes, etc. for the race or class also requires a request (a white-skinned Chultan, black-skinned elf, tiefling with devil horns, aasimar with wings, etc.).


-    IMPORTANT: Leave the subrace field blank if you do not want one of the races indicated above! Adding an unrecognized word to the subrace field will prevent you from entering the game world.
-    Do NOT add any other words to Subrace field in the character creation screen than those listed here! As above, adding an unrecognized word will prevent you from entering.
-    Outsiders by their nature are extremely susceptible to certain magical spells, such as Banishment and Word of Faith.
-    Light Sensitivity: If you're exposed to bright light then your eyes become overstimulated and you'll suffer the following penalties: -1 to attack rolls, Search checks, and Spot checks.
-    Heritage Feats: Some of our races have an optional Heritage Feat that will allow the character to gain some extra traits normally inherent to their particular subrace, such as Svirfneblin gaining Spell Resistance and other things. This feat must be taken in Epic Levels, but is not required to play the character. DO NOT take this feat if your race does not have an associated Heritage Feat, as indicated in the Races listing on the forum. It will be a wasted feat.

Use this console to activate your subrace and receive any abilities adjustments or special qualities it may have.

You will be booted for the changes to take affect after confirming the change.

Go through here for character maintenance features:

     Head Changer
     Portrait Changer

     Character Resizer
     Tattoo/Tattoo Color/Hair Color Changer

The following are rules to be used when engaging in PvP (Player vs. Player) combat. These rules are not optional (unless stated otherwise) and are to be used by ALL parties in PvP situations.

-    All PvP must have an IC reason. PvP without a sensible reason is not allowed. Your character's alignment alone is not a valid reason for PvP. Summons, such as undead, are a valid reason but do not excuse you from the below protocol.

-    You must give the other party a reasonable chance to back down from the PvP In Character. This includes a clear "out" IC that they can respond to, such as clearly telling them to leave or you will attack them. Simple threatening gestures or emotes are not enough to clearly indicate an out, as it is not clear if a character will attack or if they are just trying to intimidate. If you don't get an answer IC and the PC tries to leave, assume that they are utilizing their right to flee the situation. You can't force PvP on anyone who is trying to leave the situation.

-    IC Actions lead to IC Consequences. If you initiate a conflict (by insults or thievery, for example), you can't expect to get away with it. You cannot ignore other players' RP or declare it null.

-    You must give the other party clear IC indication of your intentions to attack, and make sure they have reasonable time to react and possibly back down IC. This requires more than one word in warning. 

-    You must set all members of the opposing party to hostile status before performing hostile actions. Use the PvP tool, the player list, or the following chat commands: /f_hostile to set everyone to hostile at once, or /f_friend to set everyone to friendly.

-    If you do not give the other party time to observe the usual protocol, you can't expect them to stick to the protocol. This means that by resting, buffing or other such preperations to hostility, you forfeit your right to a warning: The other party may attack you immediately to stop you. If you have not set them to Hostile before, you can't blame them for having to act without it. Both parties should strive to set each other to Hostile after the immediate reaction, however.

-    The above goes for fleeing from hostile situations: If you turn tail and run without a word to avoid IC consequence, you can expect to be stopped by any means possible. Always give others reasonable time to react with RP!

-    For details about subduing and killing your opponents in PvP, please refer to the PvP System details in the sidebar on the forums.

-    Assassins must inform a DM that they are about to perform a hit. If a DM is unavailable, the assassin must inform the target instead. It is advised that you screenshot as many details of an assassination hit as you can, including the warning and the combat log, for DM reference.

-    If you clearly escape an altercation, you may not continue the "same" PvP later, unless such behaviour is explicitly agreed to by all involved parties. If you return to the scene of the altercation, it is a new encounter with all the above rules. Parties may agree to a "mutual aggression" pact, where it is agreed that hostilities may commence whenever these parties interact. This must be supported by previous role-play, and is generally done when two factions (such as drow houses) have on going IC disputes that end in hostilities. It is the responsibility of the faction leaders to make sure everyone involved knows about the situation. Should this be the case, please inform the DMs about this in advance so that they know what is going on.

-    Traps are considered PvP. Do not set them down to damage random people. You are responsible for your traps and their victims.

-    Taunting someone with the Taunt skill, using Turn Undead on summons, and casting spells such as Darkness are all considered initiating PvP. You should set hostile status before doing these actions.

-    If robbed, you are not required to hand over items you do not wish to give away OOC; emoting that they are transferred IC is sufficient. DMs may present exceptions to this rule.

-    If your character is captured, and the character who caught him/her wishes to keep your character locked away, they can do so for a period of 24 RL hours, without your OOC consent. However, roleplay with the captive must be provided for those 24 hours. If it is not, then you cannot force the captive character to remain "locked away", unless you come to an OOC agreement on the matter. Keeping a character captive for longer than 24 RL hours requires the OOC consent of the player of the captive PC. In certain instances a DM can enforce captivity, but this is rarely done. Again, screenshots are advised. Settlement bans for more than 24 hours must be approved and communicated by a DM.

DO'S AND DON'TS

-    Do not log in with another character to do something your current character began. (i.e. To raise your party or to attack another PC).

-    Do not log in with multiple computers at the same time. This is also known as multiboxing, and is a bannable offense if you are caught doing it.

-    Do not log in with any character to do anything OOC. You can't just decide that your character isn't doing something that you are having them do. The only OOC rooms are those attached to the Entry and the Travel Agency/Faction Portal Room.

-    Do not exploit bugs and glitches within the Neverwinter Nights game. If you are unsure what is considered an exploit and what isn't, please ask! This includes any third-party tools that modify character appearances in-game such as adding wings or tails. Client-side overrides that do not affect the module or the way other players play or perceive you are fine. Hackers will be banned without discussion!

-    Do not resort to PvP (Player vs Player) battle without ample IC (In Character) reason. Senseless killing of other characters will resort in harsh punishment. Simply being evil is not reason enough to kill someone. If you do enter into RP-inspired PvP that results in deaths of any PC (Player Character), you must provide an OOC raise for that character (either by yourself, or arrange for someone else to do it). For more information on the PvP rules, see the Forum.

-    Do not camp any spawns, this means you can't sit on the same spawn and bring it out 3 or 4 times. This is especially so for boss spawns. If you want to go after epic bosses, leave and come back to do another round of the hunting area and let other people have a chance at it.

-    Do not metagame. Metagaming includes asking for a raise OOC, sending tells for help, and having a player port to your dead character with the purpose of raising it. Players caught doing this will be docked one level, and have half of their gold taken away. Multiple offenses will result in a ban from the game.

-    Do not transfer items or gold from one of your own characters to another of your own characters. This is referred to as muling and, if caught, all involved characters will be stripped.

-    Do not use your "Use Magic Device", or UMD skill to activate these items with a class specific OOC warning of use limitations if you do not have the appropriate class levels. The item will be removed from your character without compensation if you are found to be doing this.

-    Do not spam voicesets. (This means using the same your voiceset repeatedly and flooding chat). To experiment with a voice set, please find a secluded place where nobody else is around (there are plenty of these).

-    Do not run ahead of another group, when hunting. Do not collect treasure from corpses that your party did not kill.

-    Do not attempt to determine the acts of NPCs or history of Amia. That is for the DMs to decide. If you wish to take part in Amia's historical events, or roleplay a character that had a part in the making of Amia's history, contact a DM.

-    Do not give your characters titles that they supposedly earned on Amia, unless a DM grants you that title. If your character's past in some other land or plane involved him/her having a title, that is fine, as long as you don't claim to have any unearned influence on Amia. Note: Legitimate nobility which means you still retain that influence elsewhere must be requested prior to the character's creation.

-    Do remember, that only the DMs play gods and NPCs. That's why they are called Non-Player Characters. Making decisions for NPCs is not allowed and is considered a form of metagaming.

-    Do remember that each settlement has its own set of laws, and it's a good idea to get to know them when you frequent these areas.

-    Do remember, that explicit sexual (cybering) or graphic torture roleplay is not permitted in any channel. This includes sitting silently somewhere in a private area, clothed or unclothed, with another person. If a DM comes across you in such a position, they may believe it to be a compromising situation and you may be booted or banned. You can either log off and continue elsewhere or simply "fade to black" and skip roleplaying it out.

BASIC RULES

Every game has a set of rules to follow to ensure everyone has fun on a fair and level playing field. Amia has a few very basic rules each player is expected to follow:

Respect your fellow players and DMs at all times. We are all here to enjoy ourselves while playing the game. PCs may have conflict between one another, or be disrespectful and even violent, but their players are expected to separate the In Character (IC) from the Out of Character (OOC) and treat one another with respect. Conflicts of an OOC nature will happen from time to time, but if players maintain a healthy respect for one another then they will be able to resolve these issues on their own. In the instance that this cannot be done, a DM should be asked to mediate the dispute. When a DM makes a decision, the decision is final. Not every decision of a DM will be pleasant for every player, but the DMs ask that you please do not argue the matter in game (IG) but instead discuss the issue by private message (PM) on the forums. This allows the DM to continue DM'ing for the others players and allows you time to relax before approaching a DM about the dispute. Complaints about a DM ruling should be directed to the particular DM in question, or to any of the DMs listed as Mediators on the forums.

Respect the setting. Only DMs can decide the actions and opinions of NPCs, including the deities, and only the PC's player can determine the actions and opinions of the PC. This rule applies both IG and on the forums. The only mechanical rules that apply to all PCs are the mechanical rules governing the NWN game. Outside rules, such as from another game, or from the Dungeons & Dragons (DnD) Pen-and-Paper game (PnP), are not mandatory and may only be observed with the express consent of all players involved. DMs may sometimes introduce alternative rulesets that are the exception, however. Knowledge of Forgotten Realms lore is not required to play on Amia (though it is encouraged). Sometimes DMs will make choices that seem contrary to Forgotten Realms lore, but it is the DMs prerogative to do so. Any complaints or questions about the setting or these decisions should be directed to the DM in question, or to any of the DMs listed as Mediators on the forums.

Respect your boundaries. A PC is limited to having only the skills and abilities listed on the character sheet, the items in the inventory, and the knowledge that is reasonable for the character to know. There are exceptional circumstances that can be granted by a DM, or interpreted within the realm of common sense. A general rule of thumb is that unless it exists on the character sheet or in the inventory, or has been approved by a DM, the PC should never possess anything that would provide him or her any mechanical benefit. In addition, we expect the roleplay to remain within the boundaries of good taste. Therefore, rape and pedophilia are prohibited. Adult RP (sexual encounters or excessive, graphic torture) can only be written into the private Tell channel between two characters. Never do these styles of RP in public channels, or you can risk being banned. Each player has a different tolerance level for graphic roleplay, so please be mindful that one person's tickle torture is another person's disembowelment.

Use common sense. As one of our longtime players is fond of saying, "common sense isn't common." Be that as it may, use it to the best of your ability in all of your actions and interactions. We will be sure to inform you if your common sense is uncommon.

Enjoy yourself and be committed to helping others enjoy their time on Amia, as well. Goodwill towards your fellow player goes a long way towards building an important sense of community on the server.

Thank you for observing these basic rules!

WHAT IS AMIA?

Amia is a Neverwinter Nights (NWN) roleplaying server that has been online since 2004. Our server is based in a home-brew version of the Forgotten Realms (FR), a setting in the popular Dungeons & Dragons roleplaying game.

Our gameworld takes place on Amia: Island. It is a popular island far west of the Sword Coast in the middle of the Trackless Sea. On the island are several hubs of activity: the troubled trade city of Southport and its much smaller suburb Frontier's Rest; the pious duchy of Fort Cystana; the charming hin village known as The Dale; Moonpier, the humble fishing village; and the elven enclave of Winya Ravana. There is also plentiful adventure to be found in exploring the various coastlines, the dark Amia Forest, the festering Quagmire, the depths of Darkhold and the Skull Peak's grand summits, as well as several tombs and dungeons full of wealth and danger.

Also represented on our server are environs both original and familiar: the inhospitable Ruathym and its neighbor, the damned Caraigh, the wintery dwarf-home Barak Runedar, the hoary reaches of the northern Frozenfar, and the dark underbelly of the Forgotten Realms, the deadly Underdark. You may meet other adventurous characters in the grim jarldom of Wiltun, rustic Ceyren's Mill, backwater Howness in Forrstakkr, and the austere communities in Ostland. Or dare to explore the wilderness alone at your own peril.

A system of boats and portals allow transport between many of these locations, creating one huge module covering most of the Sea of Swords.

Amia's DMs and Designers work diligently to create a module that is rich in story, adventure and action to satisfy a wide range of gamers.

Amia can always be improved, however. We, the Dungeon Masters (DMs) and Developers, do our best to try to enhance your experience here. Please help us in doing so by reporting any bugs and exploits or giving us your ideas for improvement in the Improving Amia forum or by simply sharing your experiences about the server in the General Discussion forum. You can also find helpful information in the General Discussion forum, the Lore forums, and linked in the forum's sidebar. You can also keep track of the events and stories on the server by utilizing the many story-based, city-based, and faction-based forums.

All of this and more can be found at https://www.amiaworld.com

If you have questions, please don't be afraid to ask a DM or post your question on the forums. We also have a strong community on Discord, the link for which you can find on the forums.

WHAT IS A ROLEPLAYING SERVER?

A roleplaying server is different from an action server (based around building a character and fighting monsters with minimal interaction with other players), a social server (featuring largely unregulated interaction with other players in a casual setting), or a Player vs. Player (PvP) Arena server (where players build characters with the intent of fighting other players' characters.) On a roleplaying server in general, a player creates a character (like a character in a storybook) with the intent of interacting with other player characters (PCs) and non-player characters (NPCs), who are controlled by DMs. On Amia, we encourage players to roleplay with others more than they solo dungeons, chat, or kill each other, even though we have incorporated some elements of those other types of servers into our own.

Roleplaying is pretending to be the character you have created instead of being you. In fact, it is good to create a character that is unlike you in many ways, especially if you are new to roleplaying. In the course of roleplaying, the character will experience consequences both positive and negative, and if the character is too much like you those consequences can feel personal. For example, if you create an elven archer, then you pretend to be an elf who has lived his or her life by the bow rather than who you are (a bored data entry clerk, a high school cheerleader, a particle engineer). Although we want you to have fun in Amia, we also want you to do so while roleplaying. The art of roleplaying does not come naturally to everyone, so here are some helpful hints:

Consider the PC's motivation. Is your PC motivated by greed? By fear? Does he or she have noble or selfless goals, evil or selfish goals? Does he or she live by a code of conduct? Think about what makes the PC adventure, or about what makes the PC say and do the things the PC says and does. Asking yourself "why" is a very important skill when roleplaying and will serve you well.

Also consider the PC's background. Where was your PC born? Does your PC have family? What has happened in your PCs life, where has the PC traveled, what kind of jobs or duties has the PC performed, if any? The more detail you can put into your PCs background, the more material you have to work with, and much of it will contribute to the PC's motivations.

Consider the PC’s idiosyncrasies. An idiosyncrasy is a detail about the character that is peculiar to him or her, something that defines the PC and makes him or her memorable even if the detail does not seem relevant. What quirks does the PC have? Alcoholism? A dislike of anyone taller or shorter? Does the PC stumble when running into battle? Always wear yellow? Never like to sleep in the same place twice? Idiosyncrasies give a character flavor and can lead to some enjoyable roleplay.

As always, if you need further help, feel free to ask your fellow players, a DM, or post your questions on our forums. And of course, feel free to join us on Discord!

We have changed many of the Bioware standard spells, abilities, classes, feats, and summons for balance and a variety of others reasons. The number of changes is far too large to display here. Please review this custom content on our forums: 

https://www.amiaworld.com

You can find it under the Systems or Changes sections linked on the sidebar.
A searing shaft of white light descends from some unseen place above.

On April 13, 2015 sad news was brought to our small community -

"To all of Tim's friends, sadly today Tim lost his battle and has left us. He stayed strong and fought hard to the end, at peace at last he left calmly and with honor. Will post details of Tim's farewell soon. Love to Tim from Mum and Elizabeth"

Although most of us never met Tim, Selvec Drakon, in person, we had the opportunity to enjoy his company in the forums and here in the game. As a community we all feel that someone special was taken from us to soon, and he will be missed.

Personally, I got to know Tim briefly through two of his characters, Xal and Calin. For me, Calin will always be the more memorable of the two. Tim showed great strength and honor through Calin and it struck me as something he genuinely possessed in person. You will be missed by many Tim, and we all hope you are in a far, far better place now.
~ msheeler / Isildur

I remembered his War Knight, Calin Katar and the skill at which he both lead, and educated others on the way of the Warrior. Vaelmith had gone to him to learn to help improve his knowledge of tactics and leadership when he had improved in the Weave Knights and was potentially on his way to a leadership position.
~ Grymia / Rogaku

I mostly knew Tim through his drow character, Xal, though I did get to RP some with Calin. I remember being pleasantly surprised at how well he RPed two such different characters. Most of all, I will remember him for his exceeding kindness. He liked to hide a compassionate soul with a wicked humor, but that kind soul peeked through. He was one of the most respectful people I've RPed with, a gifted artist and musician, a loving son and brother, and a good friend. I'm sure his puppy will miss him too, but I hope that dog gives his family some love and comfort now that his light has left this world.
~ Merrien 

I cannot say much better words then this myself. I knew Selvec only briefly and I rather enjoyed speaking with him as a person. I am sad to see him go let alone in such a way. My heart goes out to his family and I hope he has found peace where ever he has gone. Cheers Selvec. I shall pray for your family.
~ SkyfallingHaven

Selvec greatly influenced the way I developed on this server, one of my inspirations for making a War Knight, and truly just a fantastic person. Strength and honor Timmy, you'll be remembered in high thoughts.
~ TheCortroy

I met Selvec only briefly on a few occasions once in RP, once when he was client side, both times had significant impact on my RP experiences here. I never got to know him well, but what I did know of him was, he was as some have said, a nice guy with wicked sense of humor as my unseelie feytouched BG found out.
~ TheLastDragonRider

I didn't speak to him much, but when I did it was always a good time. I hope he is never forgotten.
~ kalcibone

Well... shit. Red Knight was always cooler than Tempus, and Calin showed that in spades. I liked Selvec. He was a good dude. I'll miss him.
~ TormakSaber

I never RP'd much with the guy when he was around, but I always liked what I saw from a distance. My condolences to his family and friends. I was sad to hear this news.
~ Nivo

I have many fond memories of interacting with Xal, even if I didn't know Tim himself well. He was a great and fun dude though and will be missed.
~ Rigela

We talked more OOC than IC actually, and he always made me feel less intelligent, than I think I am. Do I feel smarter now? No, I feel at a loss, even though it's been a long while since we spoke. I'm saddened too, and it brings me closer to my own mortality. I fear death. See you on the other side, man, and we can finish that talk about class balance.
~ Kudark

Calin and Crunch had a lot of good times together, especially when it came to arguing about the Red Knight vs Tempus. I talked to Selvec long after I left the War Knights. He was an unbelievable rp'er, and an even better man. Strength and Honor, Selvec. You'll be missed.
~ davis114

A decade ago, Selvec had the misfortune of being stuck in the same time zone as me. Surprisingly, we got along well: we both understood one another and experienced the same frustrations on a server very different to today. During the long, DM-less nights of the Aussie time zone, the Aussie/Kiwi rivalry between us made some very entertaining times: it made the arduous task of level grinding bearable, even more so when Metalien (a pom) was dragged into it and we reminded him that the best of the British became the Aussies and Kiwis of today. On the slow nights where standing in Cordor was all most people could be stuffed doing, Xal was always around and usually present for the shenanigans at my character Jack's expense. It was quite common for the two of them to throw insults at one another for a past time, similar to what myself and Selvec did to one another in good humor. Selvec's greatest contribution for me though was his character Kroann Bloodbeard. Selvec was obsessed with Duergar and he also believed that there was more to the Underdark then just Drow: a sentiment that greatly influenced my later years on the server and my general interest in the Underdark itself. If it wasn't for him, I would not have created my Orog character or un-archived the Scholar to give things another crack. Indirectly, his influence gave me my shot to wear the DM hat. I never got the chance to thank him for that which is a shame. I do miss gaming with him. Fate is cruel, but I'm glad to hear he didn't give up. He fought: that's what mattered and that's what he'll be remembered for. R.I.P mate.
~ Galenson

He was a good friend and a good rp'er I will look back fondly of my memories with him, you might have been my enemy in character, but I enjoyed every second bantering with you. Requiescat In Pace.
~ Kraniumbrud

Calin plays a prominent role in my first memory of this server and that event is the reason I stuck it out and stayed here this long. The world lost a cool dude.
~ DerkDerkistan

Selvec was a cool chap. His character Xal will always remain my favorite drow PC, mostly because he was a continuous thorn in Gorthod's side. As well as being an awesome player, he made a damn good DM too, I saw his events topside and as a player and you could tell he actually put a lot of thought into the events. Despite all this, it's the player I'll miss the most, and his awesome friendship.
~ Silent2001

I have really good memories about him. He was a great and resourceful person and a good friend. While I had a lot of IC interactions with him I mostly had ooc conversations with him. Oddly enough our characters always had a form of rivalry Calin vs Yaston or Xal vs Glendil about who is being the cooler knight or bard. However, most of the times they had the same opinion on the actual events. 

He was a great contributor to the server, as a player, a DM or a Dev. I hope that he is resting in peace and my condolences to the family.
~ Lutra

I began playing my War knight Kaldamorte Korvath the same week that Calin Katar was introduced to the order of the flaming blade. We squired side by side under War Lord Crunch and climbed through the ranks together as time went on. I was happy to see his character in the play list whenever I logged in for war knight RP because I knew how he enriched and furthered storylines. I will miss the interactions with his various characters but Calin Katar most of all. R.I.P. Tim, you will be remembered forever in the minds and hearts of the Amians whose lives and RP you've touched.
~ elmmaster

I think perhaps elmmaster has summed up what we all want to express quite nicely...

"You will be remembered forever in the minds and hearts of the Amians whose lives you've touched."
Go here if you need to wait for stuff. Please don't loiter in the Entry room unless you need a DM and are waiting for one to be freed up.

Please examine the objects in this area to familiarize yourself with the setting and rules of this server. You can also review this information and more on Amia's forum: https://www.amiaworld.com

Please note the Racial Information next to this statue.

When you are ready to enter the IC (In Character) game world, click on the glowing angel statue. You will have a brief dialogue, and then you'll be able to click it again to go in-game. Before you do this, read the little orb next to it.

You can also explore the other OOC (Out of Character) rooms for maintenance or if you need to do something else before going in-game. Each room links back to this main entry area so you can explore them all and then enter the IC game world. Once you go inside, you can't reach the entry again on your own until the server resets.

If you have read all of this information, please do not loiter in the Entry. You can use the Waiting Rooms opposite this statue.

This is the Beta release of Enhanced Edition for Amia, freshly arrived from 1.69!

As such, the Amia Development Team is fully prepared to tackle any bugs or weirdness you may come across. Most features should work nice and smoothly, but don't be too concerned if you find something exceptionally strange.

We have an area on our forums (https:www.amiaworld.com) where you can post any bugs you come across. With your help, we'll be able to smooth out all the wrinkles and get Amia Enhanced Edition in tip-top shape!

Enjoy the game and make sure to read everything if you're not familiar with us!

This guide will help you get started as smoothly as possible:

In your inventory you will find a number of items, aside from the standard starting gear. You can examine each of these items to get a better idea of what each of them do, so keep them in mind as you go through the game.

Next to this orb you are reading is a statue named "Click me to Enter the Game". When you click this after the initial setup dialogue, you will be teleported to a room that allows you to start in a variety of different settlements on Amia. This is known as The Travel Agency and you will be able to use the statue to reach this place whenever the server resets (it is an 8-hour reset cycle). You will also be teleported to The Travel Agency if you have to respawn when you die in the game. Use the Travel Agency to retrace your steps to the location closest to your last one or head back to a town at your leisure - but the room itself is OOC, so don't refer to it In Character.

If you're just starting out, we highly recommend that you head to the opposite end of the Travel Agency and use the 'Wave & Serpent Adventuring Guild' statue. This will take you to a safe area with access to shopkeeps, rentable rooms, and your very first quest: The Recall Stone.

The main foyer is home to many things, but primarily a group of traveling dwarf merchants who sell basic +1 to +4 gear. If they are too expensive, Haur (another dwarf) sells the most basic of equipment outside the inn in Frontier's Rest, by the Trade Hall. But keep these dwarves in mind for the future and let's focus on the first quest.

Leave the main foyer and you'll find yourself in the Rusty Hoe Taphouse portion of the Guildhouse. This is a good place to interact with others and relax with a pint. Beyond this spot is a set of stairs leading up to rentable rooms and to the Adventuring Guild portion of the Guildhouse. If you go through the labeled door, you will find a woman named Sarah in the first room. She has a green name, which is noteworthy. All our quest-givers have green names.

Sarah will give you your aforementioned first quest, which will grant you access to a magical stone that will be very important for your journey. This stone, dubbed a Recall Stone, will allow you to teleport to Recall Pylons found  throughout the world. This quest will take you outside of the building and into Frontier's Rest, so pay attention to the steps she tells you. If you forget anything she said, she'll give you a hint if you talk to her again and you can also re-read the steps on the little quest note in your inventory.

Feel free to take this time to explore the Guildhouse and Frontier's Rest. There are more shopkeeps throughout the areas and several Job trainers are dotted around the town and in the buildings. The Amia Job System is fairly straightforward. You can have two jobs: one primary, and one secondary. Each job allows you to do different things, - some have direct abilities or interactions with yourself or other players, and others allow you to craft objects or easily harvest materials. All jobs offer some measure of experience points that do not require direct combat. More information on the Job System can be found on the forums. Look at the sidebar there for the quick links to our systems.

You don't have to choose a Job yet if you don't want to. For now, complete Sarah's Recall Stone quest. If you click her again after completing the quest, she will give you further instructions regarding what to do: head downstairs from Sarah to a door with a sign next to it labeling it the Portal Chamber. You'll find it between the Foyer and the Taphouse. Inside the Portal Chamber, find the Recall Pylon (feel free to check your minimap) and then left click on it to attune your stone to this location. Each portal in this room can be examined to give you an approximation of what level party is best suited for the area. Don't use any of them for now, unless you're an Underdark race and want to go to L'Obsul for the starter quests and more appropriate areas located there.

In your inventory you have an item called a Party Advertiser. If you use this item and click on yourself you will place yourself in a list that tells other players that you are looking for a party to adventure with. A large amount of areas on Amia are rather dangerous, so roleplaying and traveling with a party is considerably safer. If you wish to see who is looking for a party, activate the Party Advertiser and click on an empty spot on the ground. The information will appear in your combat log.

Once you have a party, we advise you to leave the Wave and Serpent Adventuring Guild and head south to the nearby city of Southport. Feel free to explore the city, as there are interesting shops and locations therein. The dwarf located in the East District here sells Alchemist's Fire, which is incredibly useful for a low-level character.

If you think you are ready for a bit of combat (make sure you have purchased some armor, weapons, and even some of that Alchemists Fire!), head down the sewer grate within the city's East distrct. There you will find Malcer the Sewer Cleaner (with a green name) looking for help. Talk to him for your next task. Tip: Make sure to listen to everything he has to say, as it may help you on your quest. This is good practice for all quests you encounter. Quest-givers often point you to the next quest, as well, so make sure to talk to them again after you complete their task.

If you have any further questions we highly suggest that you check out the website, forums, and Discord, where you can ask for advice, make new friends, and further your adventure!

Website: https://www.amiaworld.com/phpbb/index.php

We look forward to walking alongside you as your tale unfolds. Good luck, adventurer!

Go through here if you need to set your deity at an idol!

Note: If you already have a deity set and are above level 10, you will need DM permission to change your deity.
